tip: With JUnit5, you can parameterize your tests using a ValueSource
Selenium WebDriver has a Grid based on Docker images where you can distribute and/or parallelize your web tests
You can run WireMock in different modes: standalone, JUnit 4.x Rule, or through the WireMockServer class
TestNG was an extensive Command Line Parameters to run your tests
With REST-Assured, you can configure it to return BigDecimal instead of float or double
You can use Composed Annotation to add more than one action for your tests, like the @Test and a filter using JUnit5
Selenium WebDriver now manages your browser driver through Selenium Manager
You can easily create a Mock Server with a few lines of code using WireMock
You can create Test Groups to easily filter your test by any category with TestNG
With REST-Assured, you can choose between Jackson, Jackson2, GSON, or Johnzon to use the automatic serialization/deserialization
With JUnit5, you can use @DisplayName to add a custom name during the test execution instead of seeing the test method name
You can locate one or more elements using different locators in Selenium WebDriver
With WireMock, you can apply different configurations like network and port bindings, http, proxy, file location, gzip, cors, etc...
You can inject data into your tests using the @Parameter annotation in TestNG
With REST-Assured, you can validate your JSON Schema.
With JUnit5, you can use Java 8 lambdas inside the assertions
You can perform actions like click, type, and drag-and-drop in Selenium WebDriver
You can run WireMock standalone creating service virtualization for your necessity using the jar file or writing Java code
With TestNG, you can add dependency between tests
With REST-Assured, you can extract values from the JSON response using the JSON Path
You can use Assumptions on JUnit5 to assume you are in the expected state/place, like on the dev environment
You can manipulate the browser by doing actions like navigation, back, forward, refresh, and manage different windows in Selenium WebDriver
You can create a Stub using WireMock, adding priority, sending response headers, and specifying the response body to it
You can create tests dynamically using the @Factory annotation in TestNG
With REST-Assured, you can extract values from the XML response using the XML Path
It's ok to disable one or another test and you can do it with JUnit5 by using the @Disabled annotation
Selenium WebDriver has different strategies to wait for asynchronous actions in the browser
You can verify that a request matching a specific pattern was received, and also fetch the requested details in WireMock
With TestNG, you can ignore @Test methods in a class and/or package
With REST-Assured, you can get headers, cookies, status line, and status code from the response body
You can enable or disable a test with JUnit5 based on a certain condition, like the OS or JDK version
Selenium WebDriver has the ThreadGuard (Java only) to check that a driver is called only from the same thread that created it
WireMock can match the requests by URL, HTTP Methods, Query Parameter, Header, Basic Authentication, Cookies, Request body, and Multipart/form-data
TestNG lets you run your test in Parallel for tests, classes, or methods
REST-Assured will automatically determine which parameter type to use based on the HTTP method,  and that's ok if you explicitly add them
Tag is an excellent way to divide your tests into different test levels or any other aspect, and you can do it with JUnit5
Selenium WebDriver can work with the three types of native popup messages: alerts, prompts, and confirmations
WireMock can selectively proxy requests through to other hosts
You can create a Retry strategy to run the failed tests in TestNG
With REST-Assured, you can replace the fixed path parameter values using the named/unnamed path parameters
In a few cases, we need to order the test execution, and it's easily done with JUnit5
You can use Selenium WebDriver behind a corporate proxy
WireMock can create stub mappings from requests it has received. Combined with its proxying feature this allows you to “record” stub mappings from interaction with existing APIs
You can run tests programmatically using TestNG
With REST-Assured, you can specify a cookie to use in the request
In JUnit5, you can choose if the tests will be executed in isolation or the same instance using @TestInstance
Selenium WebDriver has a Page Loading Strategy where you can wait until it downloads all the resources or the DOM to be ready
You can create Response Templates in WireMock
TestNG lets you use the Bean Shell expression to include or exclude groups in the testsuite.xml
With REST-Assured, you can set one or more headers in the request
In JUnit5, you can create Nested Tests
Selenium WebDriver has the WebElement class where you can hold the element you locate and use all the properties it has
You can inject faulty behavior that might make it difficult to get the real service to produce on demand in WireMock
You can modify the TestNG behavior using Listeners, where the most popular is the ITestListener
You can create a class with the same payload attributes to easily manage it, and REST-Assured will do the automatic se/deserialization
Instead of classes, you can use Interfaces to use some JUnit5 annotations
You can type a text, clear its contents in an input field, or use key down/key up in Selenium WebDriver
You can simulate a Stateful Behaviour in WireMock
TestNG supports dependency injection by declaring additional parameters in some annotations
With REST-Assured, you can verify the response data like response body, cookies, status, headers, and content-type
In JUnit5, you can repeat a test a specified number of times
You can run tests in a browser located on a different machine using the Remote WebDriver in Selenium WebDriver
You can easily handle the HTTPS requests in WireMock
You can create your test suites using an XML file in TestNG
With REST-Assured, you can measure the response time
You can parameterize tests in different ways using JUnit5
It's strongly recommended to use the Page Object Model in Selenium WebDriver
You can extend WireMock to transform the responses, parameters, request matchers, and post-server actions
You can create your test suites using a YAML file in TestNG
With REST-Assured, you can do Basic Authentication like preemptive and challenged as well the digest, and form authentication with CSRF
You can customize the test display name for parameterized tests in JUnit5
It's encouraged to create a fresh browser per test in Selenium WebDriver
WireMock has a library to use together with the Spring Cloud Contract
You can display a list of the test methods that would be invoked but without actually calling them using the DryRun in TestNG
You can authenticate in OAuth 1 or OAuth 2 very easily with REST-Assured
With JUnit5, you can create a Test Template
There are discouraged behaviors you should avoid using Selenium WebDriver
You can additionally add metadata to stub mappings, which can be later used to search, delete, or simply retrieve on WireMock
You can create an external class to manage your Data-Driven Tests using the @DataProvider in TestNG
With REST-Assured, you can send a large amount of data using the multipart form data technique
In JUnit5, you can define a @Timeout where the test will fail if it exceeds the given duration
Selenium WebDriver can set browser-specific capabilities (even for IE 11)
You can use Regular Expressions in the WireMock Request Matching
There are JVM Arguments you can set to control TestNG behavior
With REST-Assured, you can reduce code duplication using the Specification Re-use
In JUnit5, you can easily run the tests in Parallel
Selenium WebDriver has a Color class to enable you to validate a color in any element
You can specify the response body using a string literal or a file in WireMock
TestNG has 5 different pre and post-conditions: suite, test, groups, class, and methods
With REST-Assured, you can inspect and alter a request and response before it's returned to the expectations through a Filter
You can use the @MethodSource in JUnit5 to refer to one or more factory methods of the test class or external classes
Select element is the only one with a special class to use in Selenium WebDriver
WireMock has a Maven plugin
Instead of annotating each method with @Test, you can apply it to the class in TestNG
With REST-Assured, you can Log all the requests and responses or only when the validation fails
In JUnit5, you have native functionality to load external data using a CSV file
You can simulate a mouse event like click and hold, drag and drop, context-click, and others in Selenium WebDriver
You can create a Docker container and turn the WireMock standalone in a Service Virtualization
You can add any information (text) to the TestNG report
With REST-Assured, you can relax or add an SSL cert to use in your tests
